context: When Céloron's expedition arrived at Logstown, the Native Americans in the area <a0_0><a0_1><b4_0>informed Céloron that <a0_2><a0_3>they owned the Ohio Country<a0_2/> and that they would trade with the British<a0_1/> regardless of the French<b4_0/><a0_3/><a0_0/>. Céloron continued south until his expedition reached the confluence of the Ohio and the Miami rivers, which lay just south of the <a1_0><a1_1><a1_2><a1_4><b5_0><b6_0>village of <a1_3>Pickawillany<b6_0/><b5_0/><a1_4/><a1_3/><a1_2/><a1_1/><a1_0/>, the home of the Miami chief known as "Old Briton". <a2_1><a2_4>Céloron <a2_0><a2_2><a2_3><b7_0>threatened<a2_3/> "Old Briton"<a2_4/> with severe consequences<a2_2/><a2_1/> if he continued to trade with the British<b7_0/><a2_0/>. <a3_4>"Old Briton" <a3_0><a3_1><a3_2><a3_3><b8_0>ignored the warning<b8_0/><a3_4/><a3_3/><a3_2/><a3_1/>.<a3_0/> Disappointed, Céloron returned to Montreal in November 1749.
